title: Current Sans Serif favs
content:
Hello,  
Interesting in knowing what are your current favorites for contemporary (humanist, geometric, or gothic) san-serif typefaces might be. Usage could be anything, but primarily wondering what faces you've purchased in the last 3 or so years that you like and why.

Here's mine:

• Bryant Pro: Nice contemporary friendly face. Very clean on and off screen

• Galaxy Polaris: Great workhorse for the studio, but a little limited. Basically our helvetica.

• Stratum: Good ultra modern font, that straddles a nice line between ultra-tech but not overly so.

Feel free to broaden the criteria for selection.

Cheers,  
Peter.
author: markatos

comments.content:
I like, amongst others, in no particular order:

- Klavika - Nice modern squarish sans  
- Legato - Good for both text and larger use, very large family  
- Fedra Sans - Especially nice when combined with Fedra Serif.  
- Locator - No special reason.  
- Engel - More friendly then Klavika.  
- Sansa (+ Soft) - Just pure genius, imo. ;)  
- Fresco Sans - Works well for body text (and then there's the serif that goes with it.)  
- Quadraat Sans - Same as Fresco Sans.

Not specifically typefaces I bought, but these came to mind right now. There are more that I like of course, but it's too late now to type more. :)

Well you stole a couple of mine (Bryant and Galaxy Polaris), but here are some more recent favorites:

**[Amplitude](http://web.archive.org/web/20150123174807/http:/www.fontshop.com/search/?q=amplitude)** by [Christian Schwartz](http://web.archive.org/web/20150123174807/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Christian%20Schwartz)  
After three years, it's still my favorite workhorse. Amplitude looks right in almost any setting — clean and readable at text sizes, vibrant and powerful in headlines. With an inktrapless version and italics on the way, soon you'll be able to use Amplitude for anything.

**[FF Strada](http://web.archive.org/web/20150123174807/http:/www.fontshop.com/fonts/downloads/fontfont/ff_strada_text/) and [FF Strada Condensed](http://web.archive.org/web/20150123174807/http:/www.fontshop.com/fonts/downloads/fontfont/ff_strada_condensed/)** by [Albert Pinggera](http://web.archive.org/web/20150123174807/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Albert%20Pinggera)  
Its warm curves can make it friendly if it needs to be, but you can use it to set serious text too. Wonderfully readable at small sizes, unique detail when large. One of few contemporary typefaces drawn by an Italian.

**[Maquette](http://web.archive.org/web/20150123174807/http:/www.fontshop.com/fonts/downloads/arstype/maquette/)** by [Angus Shamal](http://web.archive.org/web/20150123174807/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Angus%20Shamal)  
A new large x-heighted alternative in the grotesque style of [Gotham](http://web.archive.org/web/20150123174807/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Gotham) and [Proxima Nova](http://web.archive.org/web/20150123174807/http:/www.fontshop.com/search/?q=Proxima%20Nova).

• Galaxy Polaris: Great workhorse for the studio, but a little limited. Basically our helvetica.

Here are the sans-serif fonts I purchased this year:  
TheSans Office  
Parisine Plus

I wanted fonts that were readable and legible, where the italic had different letterforms than the roman, had R/I/B/BI varients, and that didn't look like everything else.

I got TheSans Office because it had what I wanted at a price I could afford. (Why do so many foundries only sell their fonts in humongous bundles at outrageous prices? Is it to keep non-pros like me from buying them?)

I went with Parisine Plus instead of Parisine because I wanted something a little more lively -- fun or quirky, if you will -- without being too eccentric.

I'm happy with my purchases, and I'm glad no one has yet cited them on this thread, because they _will_ look like everything else if everybody uses them.

We just bought leitura from dstype. It works great in the project we bought it for, but it's a bit too eccentric and narrow for being a the new workhorse of the studio.
